question: [File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Struct: PublicParameters] [Cryptographic integrity] Can an attacker manipulate the G_2 commitment base field to create fraudulent commitments that pass verification, potentially allowing them to forge dealt public keys and compromise the entire DKG ceremony? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Struct: PublicParameters] [Parameter tampering] Are the skipped fields 'table' and 'powers_of_radix' vulnerable to desync attacks where an attacker provides valid serialized parameters but the rebuilt computed fields differ from the original, causing inconsistent discrete log computations across validators? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Struct: PublicParameters] [Memory exhaustion] Can an attacker craft a PublicParameters instance with an extremely large 'ell' value (up to 255) that causes the 'table' HashMap to allocate excessive memory (2^(ell/2) entries), leading to OOM crashes during deserialization and DoS on validator nodes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Struct: PublicParameters] [Range proof manipulation] Can an attacker provide a pk_range_proof ProverKey with inconsistent max_num_chunks_padded that doesn't match the actual ell parameter, causing range proof verification to incorrectly accept invalid transcripts? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Struct: PublicParameters] [Type confusion] Does the use of generic Pairing trait E allow an attacker to instantiate PublicParameters with incompatible curve types that have different security properties, potentially downgrading cryptographic security? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: compute_powers_of_radix()] [Integer overflow] Can an attacker provide ell=255 causing 1u64 << 255 to overflow, resulting in incorrect radix values that break chunk reconstruction and allow secret manipulation? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: compute_powers_of_radix()] [Incorrect power calculation] If num_chunks_per_scalar returns an unexpected value due to edge cases in MODULUS_BIT_SIZE.div_ceil(), can this cause powers_of_radix to have insufficient or excessive entries, breaking secret sharing reconstruction? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: compute_powers_of_radix()] [Scalar field overflow] When computing powers of (2^ell), can the radix exceed the scalar field modulus causing wraparound, resulting in incorrect powers that compromise secret reconstruction integrity? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: compute_powers_of_radix()] [Zero power edge case] If ell=0, does 1u64 << 0 = 1 create a radix of 1, causing all powers to be 1 and making all chunks identical, completely breaking the chunking scheme? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: compute_powers_of_radix()] [Length mismatch] Can a mismatch between the computed powers_of_radix length and the expected num_chunks_per_scalar cause index out of bounds panics during transcript generation or verification? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: Deserialize::deserialize()] [Discrete log table poisoning] Can an attacker provide serialized parameters where the reconstructed dlog table is built with different parameters than the original, causing decrypt operations to return incorrect secrets and breaking validator key shares? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: Deserialize::deserialize()] [Base point mismatch] Does the deserialization extract G from pp_elgamal.G without validating it matches the G_2 commitment base, potentially allowing an attacker to create inconsistent parameters where encryption and commitment bases don't correspond? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: Deserialize::deserialize()] [Table size manipulation] Can an attacker provide ell values where 1u32 << (ell/2) overflows or creates tables with billions of entries, causing excessive memory allocation and validator node crashes during parameter loading? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: Deserialize::deserialize()] [Powers computation inconsistency] If the deserialized compute_powers_of_radix produces different results than the original due to floating point or rounding differences, can this cause secret reconstruction to fail across validators? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: Deserialize::deserialize()] [Group conversion vulnerability] Does converting pp_elgamal.G from affine to projective (into()) properly validate the point is on the curve and not the identity, or can an attacker inject invalid base points? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: Deserialize::deserialize()] [Malicious ell parameter] Can an attacker set ell to extreme values (1 or 255) causing the dlog table build to either fail silently or create unusable parameters that break the DKG protocol? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: Deserialize::deserialize()] [ark_de injection] Are the ark_de deserialization calls properly validated, or can malicious arkworks-serialized data exploit vulnerabilities in the underlying deserialization to inject crafted curve points? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: get_commitment_base()] [Immutable access vulnerability] Since get_commitment_base() returns a copy of G_2, can an attacker exploit timing differences or side channels when this base is used repeatedly for commitments? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: get_commitment_base()] [Zero point injection] If G_2 is the identity element (point at infinity), would get_commitment_base() return it without validation, causing all commitments to be trivial and breaking binding properties? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: Valid::check()] [No validation] The Valid::check() implementation returns Ok(()) without performing any validation - can an attacker deserialize completely invalid PublicParameters that pass this check but cause consensus failures when used? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: Valid::check()] [Missing G_2 validation] Does the absence of G_2 point validation allow an attacker to inject invalid curve points, points not in the correct subgroup, or the identity element, compromising commitment security? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: Valid::check()] [Unchecked ell bounds] Can an attacker set ell to 0 or >64 causing mathematical errors in power computations and chunk size calculations that break the PVSS scheme? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: Valid::check()] [pk_range_proof consistency] Does the lack of validation checking that pk_range_proof parameters match ell and max_num_shares allow inconsistent range proofs that accept invalid transcripts? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: Valid::check()] [pp_elgamal base validation] Are the pp_elgamal bases (G and H) validated to be non-identity and in the correct subgroup, or can invalid ElGamal parameters compromise encryption security? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pvss/chunky/public_parameters.rs] [Function: Convert::to()] [Secret extraction] Can an attacker with access to InputSecret and PublicParameters reverse the conversion to extract the secret_a from a DealtPubKey by solving discrete log on the commitment base? (High)
